com.apriori.collections

Interface BitStream


  • public interface BitStream
    A stream of bits. This interface is similar to an iterator, except it allows for selecting an arbitrary number of bits with each fetch. It also includes a method that allows for random access seeks over the underlying bits.

    Conceptually, this is like an I/O stream from which you can read arbitrarily sized chunks of bits as opposed to just reading bytes.

    Despite the similar name, it is not a Java 8 Stream. But a method is provided to adapt to that kind of stream.

    See Also:
    BitSequence

    • Method Detail

      • remaining

        int remaining()
        Returns the remaining number of bits in the stream.
        Returns:
        the remaining number of bits in the stream

      • currentIndex

        int currentIndex()
        Returns the current index of the stream. A stream can be "reset" to this point using jumpTo(int). A new stream can be created that starts back from this point using BitSequence.bitStream(int).
        Returns:
        the index of the next bit that would be retrieved by this stream

      • jumpTo

        void jumpTo(int index)
        Sets the current index of the stream. The bit at the specified index in the sequence will be the next one fetched by a call to next(). This can be used to perform random access in the sequence.
        Parameters:
        index - the new index
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the specified index is negative or is greater than the length of the underlying sequence

      • next

        boolean next()
        Returns the next bit in the stream.
        Returns:
        the next bit
        Throws:
        java.util.NoSuchElementException - if there are no bits remaining

      • next

        long next(int numberOfBits,
          BitSequence.BitOrder order)
        Returns the next chunk of bits in the stream. Since the bits are returned as a primitive long, the chunk size must be 64 bits or less. The next bit in the sequence will either be the least or most significant bit in the returned value. For example, if the next six bits in the sequence are as follows: 
        0 1 0 0 1 1
        Then fetching the next six bits in LSB order will return the number 50, which is 110010 in binary. In MSB order, the fetch will return the number 19, or 010011 in binary.
        Parameters:
        numberOfBits - the number of bits to fetch
        order - the order of bits in the returned value
        Returns:
        the next chunk of bits
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the requested number of bits is less than one or greater than sixty-four
        java.util.NoSuchElementException - if the requested number of bits is greater than the number of bits remaining in the stream

      • next

        long next(int numberOfBits)
        Returns the next chunk of bits in the stream. This is equivalent to the following: 
        stream.next(numberOfBits, BitOrder.LSB);
        Parameters:
        numberOfBits - the number of bits to fetch
        Returns:
        the next chunk of bits
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the requested number of bits is less than one or greater than sixty-four
        java.util.NoSuchElementException - if the requested number of bits is greater than the number of bits remaining in the stream

      • nextAsSequence

        BitSequence nextAsSequence(int numberOfBits)
        Returns the next chunk of bits in the stream. The chunk can be arbitrarily large provided that there are sufficient remaining bits.
        Parameters:
        numberOfBits - the number of bits to fetch
        Returns:
        the next chunk of bits, as a BitSequence
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the requested number of bits is negative
        java.util.NoSuchElementException - if the requested number of bits is greater than the number of bits remaining in the stream

      • asIntStream

        default java.util.stream.IntStream asIntStream()
        Provides a view of this bit stream as an IntStream. This allows code to operate on the stream in a functional way. The elements of the int streams as just bits, so each value in the stream is a zero or one.
        Returns:
        a view of the bits as an IntStream
